data.title: On the art of reaching consensus
data.meta_description: The four members of DIIV discuss democratic decision making, pushing back against the restraints of capitalism, and making creative work in a post-truth world.
data.text:
I saw the documentary that you put out about your tour with Depeche Mode, where you played Boston Garden. I was curious about how you worked on interpreting your sound for such a huge venue.

Cole: We thought so much about what to do for that show, and âHow do we appeal to Depeche Modeâs fans?â The simple answer is, we didnât really change anything. It was a cool case study in if our music works in spaces like that. When we were performing, it really felt like it was working.

Colin: I think the more dominant thing was trying to make the best possible DIIV set and do what we do the most efficiently in 30 minutes. And if people like that, then great. And if they donât, then they donât like the essence of the band.

Youâve typically taken three or four years between each album, but some bands release an album every year. Iâm curious how a longer creative process impacts the sound of each new record.

Colin: I think we need deadlines. Thatâs what pushes us to actually finish. I certainly think that some bands get overly indulgent, but I think that it just took us the amount of time to arrive at the record. We were certainly trying really fucking hard the whole time. We werenât dawdling or something like that.

Cole: I think it speaks to this time in the music industry where thereâs so much stuff you have to do in order to make money. You canât just make money off your recordings. Making albums is the primary thing we do, but itâs just not a sustainable thing. We finished this album a year ago, so if we wanted a record to come out a year from now, weâd have to have it done now.

You look at Depeche Modeâs early catalog, and the first time they took more than a year between records was Violator. Thatâs their seventh record. And thereâs so much progression and so much growth and amazing songwriting between every record and so much development from Broken Frame to Construction Time [Again], itâs like a new band every year. But I think that that was just the nature of that era, and things are different for musicians today.

Colin: This is not a comment on whether or not our music is exceptionally good, even though I do think our music is good, but we do really try to make the best possible album we can. And I think there are plenty of moments along the path where if our standards were a bit lower, the album would get done faster. We really demand a lot from each other and the band itself, and I think thatâs why it takes so long. If we made an album in one year, Iâm not sure we would get that same effect.

Frog in Boiling Water is described as the first time the band approached a record democratically. What was your system prior to that? Did the democratic process help or hinder your creativity during this album?

Cole: Each record was a step. The first record I made pretty much just by myself, and then the second record brought people in at various times as we learned to play the songs as a band. Deceiver was way more collaborative, live jamming in the room. We could probably talk for a long time about the difficulties in democratic decision-making, especially when thereâs an even number of people. We try to use the âfist to fiveâ consensus method.

Ben: Did the democratic process help or hinder the band? I think that it was obviously both. It helped get a larger quantity and volume of ideas. Thereâs a bigger pool to choose from, but then that obviously makes it more complicated. I think it helped us make better music, but it was harder to make the music because there were more ideas and voices to sift through.

Colin: Knowing what we know now, if we were able to go back and do this record again, it would be really different. Itâs a learning experience of how to communicate and coexist with people that youâre in partnership with. You learn the lessons when you learn them. The process, the conflict, made the album that we have now, and thatâs just the truth, more than it being a good or a bad thing.

Across your discography, your lyrics make both veiled and explicit references to political issues. Iâm thinking of âSkin Gameâ on Deceiver, where you call out the Sackler family by name, or the title track of your new album. How do you balance overt and more interpretive political expression?

Cole: Deceiver was like taking out the trash in terms of our personal inventory, but there were larger implications to the story of addiction involving the Sackler family specifically. That was a step into that world of a more politically driven song, but we had to deal with putting a bow on the wreckage of our personal lives.

This record is what weâve always wanted to make and been interested in, lyrically. All we talk about is politics in the band. Making a political record is such a strange world. There are so many bad political records that try to propose a solution, like, âJust vote for this party.â That felt really trite. We wanted to capture this capitalist dystopia for what it is and draw attention to the people and institutions that are the roots of these issues.

Speaking of capitalist dystopia, I was curious about the satirical Saturday Night Live music video for âBrown Paper Bag.â SNLâs milquetoast politics really represents that boiling frog that youâre talking about.

Cole: SNL is strange. They talk about politics, but itâs just the most banal, liberal institution. But we made that website, Soul Net, which was trying to propose these fake solutions. It was this weird website that was really web 1.0, conspiracy-pilled. We made that and it was so fun and a cool art project, but it felt so niche and we were like, âHow do we explode this into a world that just a normal, regular person would understand?â The first thing that came to mind was SNL.

Thereâs this post-truth phenomenon where you can just put anything online, and if itâs in the right echo chambers, itâs true. Thereâs services that you can pay to plant news articles that will show up on Google. So I paid 30 bucks to get three websites to post news articles, and then when you Google âDIIV SNL,â it says DIIV is playing SNL.

Colin: Itâs really unbelievable how many people believed it and continue to. We did an interview when we were in London with the interviewer whoâs known us for a really long time and is a big fan of the band and a savvy person. He just asked, âItâs just amazing to see you guys. You went on tour with Depeche Mode and you played SNL.â I almost burst out laughing. We were unsure of whether or not he was being sarcastic, but he really thought we played SNL.

Cole: People who saw the music video on Instagram or Twitter said, âItâs in my curated echo chamber, so itâs true.â It was a funny media literacy test. We wanted it to look real, so to the people who believed it, itâs not like, âYouâre a fucking idiot,â because we did everything we could to make it appear that way.

Youâve said that Frog in Boiling Water is an album about late capitalism. How do you feel that economic structure impacts creativity?

Andrew Bailey: Thereâs a really good article by Liz Pelly, âThe Problem With Muzak,â which describes how the Spotify model of music incentivizes less creative music. Thatâs just a microcosm of something thatâs true all over the place in every aspect of art. Itâs to the point where we literally canât survive as artists unless we serve capitalism in one way or another. Itâs really frustrating.

Colin: Weâre making political music because thereâs something to be really political about right now. I think that that is part of the process of making art. Even if itâs not explicitly political, itâs a response to the system that weâre living in. Itâs part of everyoneâs experience. You want to be thankful for your inspiration in some perverted way.

Cole: We canât overthrow capitalism because we need material to write our next album about.

Colin: Itâs nice to have a villain.

Did you learn anything about being in a band from touring with Depeche Mode?

Cole: We met Dave Gahan, the singer from Depeche Mode, and he had some great advice. He said, âWhen itâs an off night and the crowdâs not responding, I just turn around and I play to the band. I play to my friends.â I was like, âWow, thatâs beautiful.â

Andrew: The importance of hype music. They listened to music to get them hyped before their set. We started doing that, and it is crazy how much of a difference it makes. I remember learning when I was a kid that the band Buckcherry listens to the full AC/DC Back in Black record before their set and I always thought it was corny, but I get it now. It does something to you.

Whatâs your hype music?
